atoms.title: Three-tier structure of Facebook Ads account hierarchy
atoms.content: Facebook Ads accounts are organized into three levels: Campaign, Ad Set, and Ad. Campaign level is where you select your advertising objective. Ad Set is where you configure targeting parameters, budget allocation, and schedule. Ad level is where you create the actual advertisement content.

atoms.title: Understand Meta ad structure before creating campaigns
atoms.content: Before advertising on Facebook, Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp, you should understand Meta's ad campaign structure to comprehend the objects you are working with and how they relate to each other. This understanding is essential for effectively setting up campaigns, ad sets, and ad creatives. Marketing API provides detailed guidance and code samples to implement this correctly.

atoms.title: Use Marketing API to create and manage ad campaigns
atoms.content: Marketing API provides a set of Graph API endpoints and features to help you advertise on Meta technologies. The API allows you to perform key operations including modifying, pausing, and deleting ad campaigns.

atoms.title: Start with daily budget of 200-500k VND for initial testing
atoms.content: When beginning your Facebook Ads campaigns, allocate a daily budget between 200,000 and 500,000 VND for testing purposes. This budget level is sufficient to gather initial data and identify winning ad variations before scaling.

atoms.title: Demographics targeting includes age, gender, and location
atoms.content: Demographics targeting on Facebook allows you to filter audiences by age, gender, and geographic location. These are fundamental demographic parameters that help narrow your audience to specific population segments.

atoms.title: Interest-based targeting reaches users by their preferences
atoms.content: Facebook's interests targeting option allows you to reach users based on their stated preferences and interests. This helps you connect with audiences who have demonstrated interest in topics relevant to your product or service.

atoms.title: Behavior targeting uses user purchase and activity patterns
atoms.content: Behavior targeting on Facebook focuses on user purchasing behaviors and shopping patterns. This allows you to reach audiences based on their demonstrated buying habits and online activities.

atoms.title: Lookalike audiences find users similar to your customers
atoms.content: Lookalike audience is a Facebook feature that identifies and targets new users similar to your existing customers. You can create lookalike audiences by uploading your customer list or using Pixel data from your website visitors.

atoms.title: Lookalike 1% provides most accurate audience matching
atoms.content: When creating lookalike audiences, the 1% lookalike option provides the most accurate matching to your source audience. This setting targets users who are most similar to your existing customers.

atoms.title: Lookalike 5-10% reaches broader audience with less precision
atoms.content: A 5-10% lookalike audience reaches a much larger pool of potential customers compared to the 1% option. Use this broader lookalike range when you want to prioritize reach over targeting precision.

atoms.title: Marketing API provides endpoints to manage and analyze audiences
atoms.content: Marketing API provides essential endpoints to help developers manage audiences and analyze ad campaign insights. These tools are part of the Marketing API and are used to optimize advertising across Meta platforms including Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp.

atoms.title: Facebook Pixel is a JavaScript code for tracking conversions
atoms.content: Facebook Pixel is a JavaScript code snippet that you install on your website to track user conversions. It captures conversion events and provides data that helps you measure the effectiveness of your advertising campaigns.

atoms.title: Facebook Pixel enables retargeting of website visitors
atoms.content: After installing Facebook Pixel on your website, you can use it to retarget visitors who have viewed your site but haven't converted. This allows you to show ads to people who have already demonstrated interest in your business.

atoms.title: Install Facebook Pixel early in your advertising setup
atoms.content: You should install Facebook Pixel on your website from the beginning of your advertising efforts. This allows you to start collecting conversion data immediately, which improves campaign optimization from day one.

atoms.title: Conversions API is the primary tool for tracking conversions
atoms.content: Conversions API is part of Meta's Marketing and Commerce suite, allowing developers to send conversion data from their servers directly to Meta. This is one of the most important tools in ad optimization and campaign performance tracking. The API works alongside Meta Pixel to provide comprehensive conversion data.

atoms.title: Facebook Pixel optimizes ad delivery using conversion data
atoms.content: Facebook Pixel data helps optimize your ad delivery by providing conversion information to Facebook's algorithm. The platform uses this data to find and show ads to users most likely to convert.

atoms.title: Scale budget gradually by no more than 20% per day
atoms.content: Once you identify a winning ad, increase your daily budget gradually, limiting increases to no more than 20% per day. This gradual scaling approach prevents disrupting Facebook's learning phase and maintains campaign stability.

atoms.title: Learning phase requires 50 conversion events within 7 days
atoms.content: Facebook's learning phase is when the platform analyzes data to optimize ad delivery. During this phase, you need to achieve at least 50 conversion events within a 7-day period for the system to optimize effectively.
atoms.verification_note: No information about Facebook learning phase or 50 conversion event requirement found in baseline references

atoms.title: Learning phase causes high and unstable CPA initially
atoms.content: During the learning phase, your cost per acquisition (CPA) may be higher than normal and can fluctuate significantly. This is expected behavior as Facebook gathers data to optimize your campaigns, and stability improves once the learning phase completes.

atoms.title: A/B testing should focus on one variable at a time
atoms.content: When conducting A/B tests on your Facebook Ads, test only one element per test cycle. This could be the headline, image, audience, or ad placement. Testing a single variable ensures you can accurately attribute performance differences to that specific change.

atoms.title: Run A/B tests for minimum 3-5 days with sufficient data
atoms.content: Each A/B test should run for at least 3-5 days to gather sufficient data for reliable conclusions. This timeframe allows you to collect enough impressions and conversions to identify statistically meaningful performance differences.
atoms.verification_note: A/B test duration recommendations (3-5 days) not found in baseline references

atoms.title: ROAS measures return on advertising spend in currency ratio
atoms.content: Return on Ad Spend (ROAS) is a key metric that measures revenue generated for every currency unit spent on ads. It is calculated as total revenue divided by total ad spend, expressed as a ratio.
atoms.verification_note: ROAS definition and calculation not present in baseline references

atoms.title: ROAS above 3x indicates strong ecommerce campaign performance
atoms.content: For ecommerce businesses, a ROAS of 3x or higher is considered excellent campaign performance. This means you are generating 3 or more currency units in revenue for every 1 unit spent on advertising.
atoms.verification_note: ROAS benchmark of 3x for ecommerce not present in baseline references

atoms.title: Monitor CPA, CTR, and frequency for continuous optimization
atoms.content: Track multiple metrics beyond ROAS to continuously improve your campaigns: Cost Per Acquisition (CPA), Click-Through Rate (CTR), and frequency (how often your ad is shown to the same person). Analyzing these metrics together helps you identify optimization opportunities.
atoms.verification_note: Metrics monitoring guidance (CPA, CTR, frequency) not found in baseline references

atoms.title: Automatically adjust budget and bidding with custom rules
atoms.content: Meta Marketing API provides rule-based ad management capabilities to automatically adjust budget and bidding. You can set up custom rules and notifications to stop or start ads, adjust bids, and reallocate spending at different thresholds. Facebook's rule-based automation and triggers help optimize ad management more easily.

atoms.title: Video ads typically have lower CPM than image ads
atoms.content: Video advertisements generally achieve lower cost-per-thousand-impressions (CPM) compared to static image ads on Facebook. This makes video content a more cost-efficient creative format for many campaigns.

atoms.title: Use 16:9 aspect ratio for Facebook feed ads
atoms.content: When creating ads for the Facebook feed, format your video or image content in a 16:9 aspect ratio. This standard widescreen format displays optimally in the feed placement.
atoms.verification_note: Facebook feed ad aspect ratio specifications not found in baseline references

atoms.title: Use 9:16 aspect ratio for Facebook Stories ads
atoms.content: For advertisements shown in Facebook Stories, use a 9:16 aspect ratio (vertical format). This portrait-oriented format is optimized for mobile viewing in the Stories placement.
atoms.verification_note: Facebook Stories ad aspect ratio specifications not found in baseline references

atoms.title: First 3 seconds of video ad are critical for engagement
atoms.content: The opening 3 seconds of your video advertisement are crucial for capturing viewer attention. You should include a compelling hook in the first 3 seconds to prevent viewers from scrolling past your ad.
